medalpaca-13b_answer_v4:
1. Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA): In this procedure, a hollow needle is inserted into the facet joint, and an electrical current is passed through the needle to heat up and destroy the tissue.

2. Percutaneous Disc Image Guided (PIGD) Biopsy: This procedure involves inserting a needle into the suspected disc under imaging guidance, and then withdrawing the needle with the disc tissue captured in a capsule for examination.

3. Percutaneous Endoscopic Lumbar Discectomy (PELD): This procedure involves inserting an endoscope through a small incision and then removing the herniated disc tissue with small instruments.

4. Open Discectomy: This procedure involves making a larger incision and then removing the herniated disc tissue with surgical instruments and visualization.

5. Spinal Fusion: This is a major surgical procedure that involves joining two or more vertebrae together to prevent movement and relieve pain.

6. Artificial Discs: In this procedure, the natural disc is removed and replaced with an artificial disc.

As far as I know, Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is a genetic disorder that affects collagen, causing multiple fractures in childhood, but it does not seem to be a systemic condition that would require laboratory testing.  It would be treated by an orthopedist and may require surgery, but no laboratory testing is needed.

Marfan Syndrome is another genetic disorder of collagen, but it is a systemic disorder that could involve aortic aneurysm, mitral valve prolapse, and other problems.  It might require echocardiography and other testing.

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is a disorder of collagen metabolism that can present with easy bruising and other symptoms.  It can be diagnosed by a simple blood test.

I hope that this is helpful.  I would recommend that you consult with your doctor about whether any of these conditions might apply to you or your child.

medalpaca-13b_answer_v2: As a doctor, I can understand your concern. Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder that affects the bones making them brittle and prone to fracture. Whereas, EDS (Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) is a group of genetic disorders that affect the body's connective tissues. These tissues provide support and structure to the skin, bones, blood vessels, and other organs. Some of the types of EDS can cause easy bruising and bleeding, while others may not cause any bleeding problems. Some types of EDS can also cause elastic skin that can be stretched like rubber. However, there is no specific genetic test for EDS. It is diagnosed by examining the patient for specific symptoms and by ruling out other possible causes. So, please visit a geneticist for proper diagnosis and treatment. Hope this helps.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3:
Question: Do you know of a laboratory in Southern California, particularly in San Bernardino, LA, or Riverside County, that specializes in genetic testing for EDS and Osteogenesis Imperfecta, and can you tell me if the symptoms of these two diseases are alike?

Answer: Unfortunately, I don't know of a lab in Southern California. However, the symptoms of EDS and Osteogenesis Imperfecta are quite different from each other. EDS, or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, is a group of genetic disorders that affect the body's connective tissue, which provides support and structure to the skin, bones, blood vessels, and other organs. Patients with EDS may experience joint instability causing dislocations, chronic joint pain, and easy bruising. Osteogenesis Imperfecta, on the other hand, is a genetic disorder that causes bones to break easily. Patients may experience recurrent fractures, as well as other symptoms such as hearing loss and blue sclerae. It is important to seek medical attention for proper diagnosis and treatment. I hope this information was helpful.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v4:
1.	I am sorry but I am not aware of any lab that offers genetic testing for EDS and Osteogenesis Imperfecta in Southern California. However, you can visit the website of the American Board of Medical Genetics and Genomics at http://www.abmgg.org/laboratory-genetic-testing-medicare-coverage. This website provides the patient/physician with information on whether Medicare would cover the cost of the test. You can also visit the website of the Laboratory Tests Online at https://labtestsonline.org/labs/genetic-testing/types/conditions. This website provides basic information on genetic testing and lists laboratories that perform genetic testing.
2.	Comparing the symptoms of EDS and Osteogenesis Imperfecta: EDS (Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) is a group of inherited disorders that affect your body's connective tissue. EDS affects the way your body builds and maintains collagen, a protein that provides the framework for the body. There are several types of EDS. The vascular type of EDS is the most serious. It causes easy bruising and bleeding, and it's the most likely to cause death. Less severe types of EDS can cause joint problems, such as hyperextensible joints and a tendency to dislocate joints. Other types of EDS feature skin that is easily bruised or stretched, and other symptoms.
Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is a group of genetic disorders that cause bones to break easily. There are several types of OI. The most common type of OI features multiple fractures, as well as other symptoms, such as blue sclerae, hearing loss, and dentinogenesis imperfecta. Rare types of OI can cause little or no bone fractures, as well as other symptoms, such as dental problems, seizures, and vision loss.
In summary, EDS and Osteogenesis Imperfecta are two different genetic disorders with different symptoms.

3. If these worms are segmented and visible, it is most probably not a helminth infection (i.e., parasitic infection). Many non-parasitic worms also have segmented bodies. For example, earthworms, which are used in fishing, have 3-5 segments.
4. If these worms are non-segmented and visible, it is possible that you have a parasitic infection. However, there are many non-parasitic worms that are non-segmented and visible. For example, tapeworms are non-segmented and visible.
5. In any case, you should see a doctor, preferably a helminthologist (parasitologist), to determine the type of worms you have. Treatment methods differ depending on the type of worms.

medalpaca-13b_answer_original: No.  An abscessed tooth cannot cause a heart attack.  An abscessed tooth can cause inflammation and pain in the mouth and gums surrounding the infected tooth.  The infection can potentially spread to other areas of the body, but not the heart.  A heart attack occurs when there is a blockage in the coronary arteries that supply blood to the heart.  This blockage is usually caused by atherosclerosis which is the buildup of fatty deposits on the inside of the arteries.  Other risk factors for heart attack are high blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, and high cholesterol.  It is important to maintain a healthy diet, exercise regularly, and manage any underlying medical conditions to reduce your risk of a heart attack.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1: No, this is highly unlikely.  However, untreated dental infections can increase the risk of endocarditis, which is a heart infection.  So it is possible that an endocarditis could cause a heart attack, but this is also rare.  It is very important to treat all dental infections promptly to minimize the risk of complications.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v2:
No, a tooth abscess cannot cause a heart attack. A tooth abscess is a localized infection in a tooth and has nothing to do with the heart. A heart attack occurs when the blood supply to the heart is blocked, usually by a clot in the coronary arteries. The most common cause of heart attacks are atherosclerosis, a condition where the coronary arteries become narrowed and hardened by a buildup of fatty deposits. 

If you have symptoms of a tooth abscess such as pain, swelling, or bad breath, you should see a dentist as soon as possible. For your heart health, it is important to maintain a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet, regular exercise, and not smoking. If you have any symptoms of a heart attack such as chest pain, shortness of breath, or fatigue, you should call 911 or your local emergency number immediately.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3:
No, tooth abscesses are not a common cause of heart attacks. 

-"The causal relationship between endocarditis and dental infections is still debatable. In a series of 9283 patients, only 0.1% had a diagnosed dental infection, and 0.2% had signs of past dental infection. In the presence of a dental infection, the clinical and echocardiographic findings were highly suggestive of infective endocarditis, but blood cultures were negative in 60% of cases. The diagnosis of infective endocarditis was made by surgery or by long-term antibiotic therapy on the basis of cultures or PCR. The most frequent bacteria isolated by culture or PCR were viridans group streptococci. In the absence of a dental infection, a bacterial infection was only found in 1.3% of cases (1)."

Reference:  http://www.cardiobrief.org/2016/08/19/heart-attack-and-dental-abscess/
medalpaca-13b_answer_v4: No, abscessed teeth would not be expected to increase the risk of a heart attack.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v5: No, an abscess in a tooth would not be expected to trigger a heart attack. However, severe stress from any cause can raise the risk of a heart attack, and the stress of toothache and the fear of an abscess may be sufficient to cause this. It is therefore possible, though unlikely, that the occurrence of a heart attack in someone with a tooth abscess should be investigated.

1. Diabetes is not the cause of weight gain in an obese child.

medalpaca-13b_answer_v1:
1) Weight gain is not necessarily a sign of diabetes. Unlike diabetes, which causes increased thirst and urination, diabetes does not cause increased appetite. In fact, type 1 diabetes, which is usually diagnosed in childhood, causes the opposite, namely, weight loss.
2) Thirst is not necessarily a sign of diabetes either. Diabetes causes excessive urination, not thirst. Type 1 diabetes causes the opposite, namely, dry mouth.
3) If there are no other symptoms of diabetes, such as fatigue, irritability, visual problems, and wound healing problems, I would not even recommend a routine blood glucose test, which can be normal even in diabetes.
4) If his growth and puberty development are normal, I would not worry about his weight gain either. Children have increased energy needs and their increased appetite causes them to eat more than they need.
5) If his weight gain is excessive, like more than 2 pounds per month, this could be a reason for concern.
6) If you are still concerned, I would recommend a routine well-child exam, where the doctor can check his weight, height, blood pressure, and do a physical exam. Based on that, the doctor can reassure you or perform further tests, such as a finger stick blood glucose test.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v2: 5-year-old son's excessive hunger and thirst, combined with grandfather's diabetes, could indicate a risk of diabetes, despite being very active.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3:

2. The most likely cause for the 5 year old's hunger and weight gain is his genetic background. Some children are programmed to be hungry and to gain weight. This is not diabetes. If the child has other symptoms such as frequent urination, thirst, or fatigue, then diabetes should be considered. 
3. The most likely cause for the 7 year old's eating little and being underweight is his temperament. Some children are cautious and timid, and will only eat if they are very hungry. This is not diabetes. If the child has other symptoms such as frequent urination, thirst, or fatigue, then diabetes should be considered. 
4. I recommend that the parents of these boys make sure they have healthy food available and don't reward the 5 year old with food or high calorie snacks for every little thing. Make sure he gets plenty of exercise. And I recommend that they discuss their concerns with their pediatrician.

I would suggest you the following: a. Measure the blood pressure, height and weight of your child (and do this regularly). This will help to determine if the child is overweight or not according to standard guidelines. b. Get active 60 minutes a day for the whole family. c. Limit screen time (TV, Computer, Mobile) to 2 hours a day for the whole family. d. Last but not the least, encourage sports and physical activity and do regular monitoring and follow up. medalpaca-13b_answer_v5:
1. Weight alone cannot be used to determine whether a child is at risk for diabetes.
2. Diabetes is a metabolic disorder resulting from either inadequate insulin production (Type 1) or failure of insulin to function normally (Type 2) which leads to high levels of glucose in the blood. Prolonged elevation of blood glucose levels can lead to microvascular and macrovascular complications.
3. Genetic factors, environmental factors (e.g. diet, physical activity), and obesity are all risk factors for diabetes.
4. It is recommended that children be screened for diabetes using fasting blood glucose (FBG) level measurement between the ages of 10 and 12. However, if a child has symptoms of diabetes (e.g. polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss, etc.) or risk factors for diabetes, they may be screened earlier.
5. Childhood obesity is an important risk factor for diabetes and other chronic diseases. However, not all obese children will develop diabetes.
6. If you have concerns about your children's health, growth, or development, I recommend that you consult with a healthcare professional who can perform a comprehensive evaluation and provide you with individualized recommendations.

medalpaca-13b_answer_original:
1. Male pattern baldness is definitely related to circulation.
2. The hair shaft is made of a protein called keratin. 
3. Protein breakdown into amino acids is done by an enzyme called protease. 
4. Amino acids are transported via the blood stream to the hair follicle.
5. Amino acids are used by the hair follicle to make new hair.
6. Hence, poor circulation can lead to poor amino acid transport and hence hair loss.
7. However, male pattern baldness is most often a genetic condition related to the hormone dihydrotestosterone (DHT).
8. DHT shortens the anagen (growth) phase of hairs and shortens the overall hair shaft length.
9. DHT does this by attaching to the androgen receptor in hair follicles.
10. This makes the hair follicle smaller and the hair shorter and finer.
11. DHT also makes the hair follicle produce more sebum and branching, which makes the hair weaker and more likely to fall out.
12. DHT is also known to reduce the number of hairs in the follicle.
13. This means that there are fewer hairs available to be transplanted elsewhere.
14. Therefore, though poor circulation may be a contributing factor to male pattern baldness, DHT is the main cause.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1:
1. Male-pattern baldness: This may be due to an inherited propensity for androgynous alopecia (male hormones) or simple genetics.
2. Illness: A variety of illnesses can cause hair loss, including thyroid problems, diabetes, and other metabolic disorders.
3. Aging: This is also known as involutional alopecia. Some people simply lose hair density as they age.
4. Stress: This is a temporary type of hair loss, usually, that occurs when the body is under stress.
5. Medication side effect: This is a possible cause of hair loss, as certain drugs (chemotherapy, radioactive implants, antidepressants, and oral retinoids) have the side effect of hair loss.
6. A hormone disorder: This may be caused by an excess of androgens (male hormones), which can block the effects of FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) in both men and women, leading to hair loss.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: This is a possible cause of hair loss, as certain nutrients such as iron, are important for hair growth.
8. Autoimmune disease: This is a possible cause of hair loss, as some autoimmune diseases cause inflammation, which may damage hair follicles.
9. Genetics: Some people are genetically predisposed to hair loss.

3. When hair is cut very short, the sharp edges of the blades may cut the hair shaft as it emerges, causing it to fall out.

4. Over time, this can lead to inflammation, infection, and scarring, which inhibits the growth of new hairs.

5. To prevent pseudofolliculitis barbae, it's best to allow hair to grow naturally or, if shaving is desired, to use a safety razor with rounded edges.

medalpaca-13b_answer_original: There is no cure for asthma, although symptoms sometimes improve over time. Asthma is a chronic respiratory disease that is characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, which can lead to symptoms such as wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath. While there is no cure for asthma, symptoms can often be managed with medications such as inhaled corticosteroids, bronchodilators, and anti-leukotriene agents. In some cases, surgery may be necessary to remove excess lung tissue or to correct any structural abnormalities in the lungs or airways. It is important for individuals with asthma to work closely with their healthcare provider to develop a personalized treatment plan that addresses their specific needs and goals.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1: There is no cure for asthma, although symptoms sometimes improve over time. However, it is common for symptoms to return.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v2:
It's hard to say "cured" of asthma. There is no one single cause of asthma, and it is likely a combination of genetic, environmental and infectious causes. As such, there is no single cure.

There are however, ways to manage asthma. There are two types of management: acute and chronic. Acute management is for when your airways are narrowed and you are having symptoms such as wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, etc. Chronic management is to try and reduce the likelihood of having acute symptoms.

There are many different inhalers, for example, that can be used for acute management. They all work a little differently, so talk to your doctor about what is best for you.

There are also oral medications that can help as a part of chronic management. There are also shots that can be given every 2-3 weeks that help with symptoms.

It's also important to avoid triggers. Some of the common triggers include pollen, smoke, stress, excitement, exercise, etc. Talk to your doctor about what you can do to avoid these triggers.

There is no cure to asthma, but there are many treatments that can help manage your symptoms.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3: Asthma is a chronic respiratory disease that affects your lungs' bronchial tubes. Symptoms include coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. While there is no cure for asthma, symptoms sometimes improve over time. With proper self management and medical treatment, most people with asthma can lead normal lives.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v4:
There is no cure for asthma. The inflammation and narrowing of the airways in asthma cannot be reversed. However, symptoms sometimes improve over time, and it is sometimes possible to stop medication.

Asthma is a chronic (long-term) illness. Although symptoms sometimes improve over time, they can return frequently and occasionally with warning.

In many patients, asthma can be controlled with proper self management and medical treatment. With proper self management and medical treatment, most people with asthma can lead normal lives.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v5:

medalpaca-13b_answer_original: 1. Endoscopy: This is usually done when acid reflux is suspected. An endoscope is a long tube with a camera on the end, that is inserted through the mouth, and down into the stomach and duodenum (the first part of the small intestine). The endoscope allows the doctor to see any abnormalities, and if a hiatal hernia is present, it can be seen as well. Biopsies can be taken during the procedure if necessary.2. Barium swallow or upper GI series: This is an x-ray procedure that involves swallowing a white liquid containing barium. The barium coats the stomach, duodenum, and small intestine, and x-ray images are taken to look for hiatal hernias, as well as other abnormalities such as strictures (narrowing of the esophagus). The test will show if there is an abnormal movement of the stomach and duodenum into the chest cavity.3. 24-hour pH monitoring: This test is done to measure the amount of acid that refluxes into the esophagus over a 24-hour period. A small tube is placed in the esophagus, and the amount of acid that refluxes into the esophagus is recorded over a 24-hour period. This test will show if the acid is damaging the lining of the esophagus, which can cause symptoms such as hoarseness, coughing, and difficulty swallowing.4. Esophageal manometry: This is a test that measures the pressure inside the esophagus, the pressure needed to start the movement of food into the stomach, and the tightness of the muscles in the esophagus and the lower esophageal sphincter (the muscle at the bottom of the esophagus that acts as a valve between the esophagus and the stomach). This test can help determine if the reflux is due to a muscle problem, such as a weak lower esophageal sphincter.

1. Surgical Procedures
There are several surgical procedures used to treat hiatal hernia and acid reflux. The most common one is Nissen fundoplication. In this procedure, the surgeon wraps the upper part of the stomach around the lower esophageal sphincter to strengthen the sphincter and prevent acid reflux.
Another surgical procedure is Laparoscopic Hill, in which the surgeon makes several small incisions in the abdomen and inserts a laparoscope, a thin, lighted tube with a camera on the end, to view the hernia. Then the surgeon uses small tools inserted through the other incisions to repair the hernia.
2. Non-surgical Procedures
There are several non-surgical procedures used to treat hiatal hernia and acid reflux. One is endoscopic sinus tarsi enlargement, in which the doctor uses an endoscope to expand the space in the tarsi area, where the upper and lower esophageal sphincters meet, to reduce acid reflux.
Another non-surgical procedure is Stretta, in which the doctor uses a special device to deliver radiofrequency energy to the lower esophageal sphincter to strengthen it and reduce acid reflux.
3. Antireflux Surgery

Whipple's disease is a rare condition that can be difficult to diagnose. It is caused by bacteria named Tropheryma whipplei. The condition is systemic, meaning it affects many organs. It mainly affects the small intestine. Other organs that may be affected include the large intestine, stomach, lungs, heart, joints, and central nervous system.
Common symptoms include diarrhea, abdominal pain, joint pain, skin rash, and weight loss. Less common symptoms include lung infections, heart valve problems, and changes in mental status.
The condition can be fatal, especially if the infection spreads beyond the intestines. The death rate is high if doctors do not diagnose and treat the condition quickly. Most people with this condition die within 1 to 2 years if it is not treated. However, some people may survive for longer periods if they receive treatment.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1:
"Without treatment, Whipple's disease can be fatal."

However, it is difficult to predict survival time, as it depends on many factors, such as the patient's general condition, age, and responsiveness to treatment. Talk to your doctor about your specific condition and outlook.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v2: 1-5 years.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3: 100% fatality. Whipple's disease is a rare bacterial infection that can affect various systems of the body. If left untreated, it can be fatal. The prognosis is good with treatment and most patients recover fully.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v4:
1. Whipple's disease is a rare bacterial infection of the small intestine that can cause diarrhea, weight loss, and other gastrointestinal symptoms.

2. Yes, it is possible to survive for that long without treatment, the longest recorded case was 32 years. But it is very rare and if left untreated, the patient might develop systemic symptoms and even death.

3. If you suspect you might have Whipple's disease, I recommend you to go to the doctor as soon as possible to start the treatment.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v5: 100% fatal if left untreated.

medalpaca-13b_answer_original: 1. Dietary modification: The first step in treating any disease is to follow a diet which helps in reducing the symptoms. In this case, dietary modification includes eating less of fermentable carbohydrates. These carbohydrates are the ones which are broken down by the intestinal bacteria into gas. So, reducing intake of such carbohydrates will reduce the amount of gas formed. Some of such carbohydrates are raffinose, lactose, sucrose, fiber, and complex carbohydrates.2. Antibiotics: In some cases, antibiotics may be required if there is an overgrowth of bacteria in the intestines. This is especially seen when there is an overgrowth of bacteria like Clostridium, which is known to produce a large amount of gas.3. Lifestyle modifications: Changes in lifestyle can also help in reducing gas formation. These include eating in a relaxed manner, avoiding swallowing air while eating or drinking, and avoiding foods that produce gas in a person.4. Medications: There are some medications which help in reducing gas formation. These include simethicone, which is commonly found as a component in many antigas preparations. Simethicone works by changing the surface tension of bile acids, thus decreasing the amount of gas formed.

medalpaca-13b_answer_v2:
1. First, you need to keep a diary of the foods you eat, the number of servings of each food, the number of servings of fermentable carbohydrates (such as fiber, lactulose, and raffinose) you eat, and the number of servings of sugar-free foods you eat.
  Also record the number of pills you take daily, the number of servings of each type of food you eat at each meal, and the number of glasses of gas producing beverages you drink daily.
2. Keep a record of the number of times you pass gas, the number of servings of each food you eat within 4 hours of flatulence, the number of glasses of gas producing beverages you drink within 4 hours of flatulence, and the number of pills you take within 4 hours of flatulence.
3. After 2 weeks, look back at your diary and see if you can find any patterns. For example, if you pass gas frequently after eating a particular food, then you may want to cut back on that food or limit it to one serving a day.
4. Keep any gas producing foods such as beans, cruciferous vegetables (such as broccoli, cauliflower, and brussel sprouts), artiplex (such as artichokes), onions, and garlic to 1-2 servings a day.
5. Try limiting gas producing beverages such as carbonated drinks and milk to 1-2 servings a day.
6. Try limiting sugary foods and sugar-free foods.
7. Try limiting foods that contain raffinose such as beans, asparagus, and cabbage.
8. Try taking an over-the-counter simethicone or activated charcoal tablet before meals.
9. Try taking a probiotic supplement containing Lactobacillus.
10. Try cutting back on the number of pills you take.
11. If you are still having problems after making these changes, then you may want to see a doctor. A doctor can rule out any serious medical problems and prescribe medication to treat chronic flatulence.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3:
1. Dietary modifications:

A. Reduce intake of gas-producing foods such as beans, cruciferous
  vegetables, mushrooms, onions, and garlic.
B. Drink fewer beverages that contain sugar.
C. Eat smaller, more frequent meals.
D. Try an elimination diet to determine which foods cause intolerance.
2. Medication:

A. Lactase supplements (lactase is an enzyme needed to break down
  lactose, a sugar found in milk; supplements can help digest milk
  better)
B. Betaine supplements (a molecule that can help break down other
  molecules in the gut, such as dietary fiber and fat; often used to
  treat irritable bowel syndrome)
C. Probiotics (live bacteria and yeasts that can help maintain a
  healthy gut and digestive function; often used to treat irritable
  bowel syndrome)
D. Anti-flatulence medications (such as simethicone, which breaks
  down gas bubbles in the intestine)
E. Anti-inflammatory medications (such as mesalamine, which can
  reduce inflammation in the intestine)
3. Other treatments:

A. Avoid smoking.
B. Increase physical activity.
C. Manage stress.
D. Lose weight.
E. Try an herbal supplement (such as enteric-coated peppermint oil
  capsules, which can help relax the muscles in the intestines and
  reduce gas production).
F. Try an elimination diet to determine which foods cause intolerance.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v4: 1. Difficulty in digesting certain foods 2. Swollen intestines 3. Increased gas production 4. Certain diseases such as celiac sprue, inflammatory bowel disease, or irritable bowel syndrome 5. Taking in too much air unintentionally while eating or drinking 6. Lactose intolerance 7. Intestinal infections such as bacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections 8. Reaction of the body to certain foods, such as lactose intolerance or celiac sprue 9. Constipation 10. Lack of exercise 11. Eating too fast 12. Eating in excess of fiber 13. Certain medications such as antibiotics, aspirin, and diuretics.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v5:
1. Rule out malabsorption:
Check for celiac disease and other causes of malabsorption like lactose intolerance and other carbohydrate intolerances.
2. Check for bacterial overgrowth:
Excessive gas production may be due to bacterial overgrowth in the intestines. A course of antibiotics may be helpful in such cases.
3. Dietary modifications:
Cut down on gas producing foods like beans, crucifers, onions and garlic.
4. Probiotics:
May help in reducing intestinal gas by increasing bowel motility and decreasing intestinal gas producing bacteria.
5. Enzyme supplements:
Can help in digesting carbohydrates better and thus reduce intestinal gas.
6. Last resort: Colonoscopy:
In case all the above measures fail, a colonoscopy is recommended to rule out any serious underlying conditions like colon cancer or inflammatory bowel disease.

medalpaca-13b_answer_v1:
1. Seborrhea: This is a common skin disorder characterized by fatty, oily skin and hair that is often greasy and limp. Seborrheic dermatitis, as it is called when it occurs on the scalp, can cause the hair to become thick and waxy. When seborrheic dermatitis affects other areas of the body such as the face, it is called seborrhea. In addition to hair and skin symptoms, seborrhea can cause difficulty swallowing, due to a condition called esophageal candidiasis. This is caused by an overgrowth of a type of yeast called Candida in the tube that carries food from your mouth to your stomach (esophagus). Antifungal medications can treat this infection.

2. Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): This is a condition that affects women of reproductive age. It is caused by changes in hormone levels. In addition to menstrual irregularities, PCOS can cause symptoms such as acne, excess hair growth (hirsutism) and weight gain. PCOS can also cause elevated levels of androgens, which are male hormones like testosterone. Androgens can cause skin to become thicker and coarser, which can include facial hair. Women with PCOS may also have elevated levels of insulin, which is a hormone that regulates blood sugar. This can cause skin to become more oily. Treatment for PCOS may include medications to regulate menstrual cycles, control androgens and insulin levels, and treat acne and other symptoms.

3. Cushing's Syndrome: This is a condition that occurs when the body is exposed to high levels of the hormone cortisol for a long period of time. Cortisol is a hormone that is produced by the adrenal glands, which are located on top of the kidneys. It helps to regulate metabolism and the immune system. Cushing's Syndrome can cause symptoms such as high blood pressure, weight gain, muscle weakness, and skin thinning. It can also cause hair loss and facial hair growth in women. C

Bipolar disorder

Hyperactivity
Impulsivity
Forgetfulness
Disorganization
Procrastination

Easily distracted

medalpaca-13b_answer_v2: The symptoms of adult ADHD include: poor concentration, disorganization, mood lability, and restlessness. These symptoms can be easily confused with depression, anxiety, or bipolar disorder.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3:
1. Inattentive (Hyperactive) Symptoms*

  Often fails to give close attention to details or makes careless mistakes in schoolwork, work, or other activities.
  Often has difficulty keeping attention on tasks or play activities.
  Often does not seem to listen when spoken to directly.
  Often does not follow through on instructions and fails to finish schoolwork, chores, or duties in the workplace (not due to laziness or boredom).
  Often has difficulty organizing tasks and activities.
  Often avoids or dislikes tasks that require sustained mental effort (such as schoolwork).
  Often loses toys, assignments, pencils, books, or tools needed for tasks or activities.
  Is often easily distracted.
  Is often forgetful in daily activities.
  Six or more of the above symptoms must be present in order to diagnose ADHD.

2. Hyperactive Symptoms*

  Often fidgets with hands or feet or squirms in seat.
  Often leaves seat when remaining seated is expected (e.g., in classroom or places of worship).
  Often runs about or climbs inappropriately in situations (e.g., in public, in school).
  Often has difficulty playing or engaging in leisure activities quietly.
  Is often "on the go," acts as if "driven by a motor," talks excessively, or blurts out answers to questions.
  Six or more of the above symptoms must be present in order to diagnose ADHD.

* These symptoms are the ones used to diagnose ADHD. The first set of symptoms (1-6) are the most common in Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder. The second set of symptoms (7-9) are used to diagnose the predominantly hyperactive type of ADHD. However, children and adolescents with ADHD may not have all of these symptoms. For example, many children with ADHD do not have symptoms of hyperactivity, and many children who have these symptoms do not have ADHD. It is important to see a doctor if you or your child's school personnel suspect that he or she may have ADHD.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v4:
Other conditions that have symptoms similar to adult ADHD are: 1) bipolar disorder, which has symptoms of manic and depressive episodes; 2) anxiety disorders, which have symptoms of fear and worry; 3) psychotic disorders, which have symptoms of delusions and hallucinations; 4) substance abuse, which has symptoms of impaired control of substance use.

Symptoms of adult ADHD itself include: 1) poor attention, such as not seeming to listen when directly spoken to; 2) hyperactivity, such as squirming, touching, and tapping; 3) impulsivity, such as answering before thinking; 4) forgetfulness, such as forgetting daily tasks; 5) disorganization, such as losing items; 6) procrastination, such as delaying tasks until the last moment; and 7) poor time management, such as failing to meet deadlines. These symptoms usually occur more often than not for a period of at least 6 months, to a degree that they interfere with social or occupational functioning.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v5: Common symptoms of adult ADHD include:  Poor concentration; Hyperactivity (as a child, but not as an adult)  Often other conditions have symptoms that can be mistaken for ADHD, such as:  Depression  Anxiety  Bipolar disorder  Stimulant abuse  Alcohol abuse  It is important to seek medical attention to distinguish ADHD from other conditions.

medalpaca-13b_answer_original:
1) LOW DOSE BIRTH CONTROL PILLS, as opposed to high dose birth control pills, can decrease your risk of preeclampsia. 
2) Exercise during pregnancy also decreases your risk of preeclampsia. 
3) Eating a healthy diet, with plenty of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, and low fat dairy products, will decrease your risk of preeclampsia.  Low fat, low calorie diets do not appear to decrease the risk of preeclampsia. 
4) Avoiding gaining too much weight during pregnancy will decrease your risk of preeclampsia. 
5) Taking your vitamins, especially your B vitamins, will decrease your risk of preeclampsia. 
6) Avoiding stress will decrease your risk of preeclampsia. 
7) Getting your blood pressure checked regularly will decrease your risk of preeclampsia. 
8) Not smoking will decrease your risk of preeclampsia. 
9) Drinking only in moderation, or not at all, will decrease your risk of preeclampsia. 
10) Having a healthy diet, low in sodium, will decrease your risk of preeclampsia. 
11) Avoiding too much travel, especially air travel, will decrease your risk of preeclampsia. 
12) Maintaining a good social support network will decrease your risk of preeclampsia.

medalpaca-13b_answer_v4: There are some strategies that may help reduce your risk of developing preeclampsia. Since high blood pressure and preeclampsia are often associated with obesity, maintaining a healthy weight may help reduce your risk. Not smoking is also associated with a reduced risk of preeclampsia, as is getting regular exercise and eating a healthy diet. If you are at high risk for preeclampsia due to a previous pregnancy where you developed the condition, your doctor may suggest medications that can help reduce your risk. Finally, there are also some tests that may help identify women at high risk for preeclampsia, such as blood tests that look at your blood pressure and blood clotting factors, and ultrasounds to look at your blood flow and the baby's growth. If you are at high risk, your doctor may suggest ways to try to reduce your risk or may recommend that you receive more frequent monitoring during your pregnancy.

medalpaca-13b_answer_original:
1. Disease-modifying drugs, such as methotrexate or biologic agents, are recommended for all patients with rheumatoid arthritis, especially middle-aged males.
2. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) may also be helpful for pain and inflammation.
3. Exercise and physical therapy can help maintain range of motion and reduce stiffness.
4. Middle-aged males with rheumatoid arthritis should be monitored for signs of heart disease, as this is a common complication.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1: The most recent developments in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis for middle-aged men are targeted synthetic drugs that block specific parts of the immune system.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v2:
1. The American College of Rheumatology (ACR) has published guidelines for the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) in men that can be helpful in daily practice.
2. The 2015 ACR/EULAR (European League Against Rheumatism) classification criteria for rheumatoid arthritis was used to classify patients into 3 groups: 
    - Patients who do not have rheumatoid arthritis. 
    - Patients who have RA but do not have active disease. 
    - Patients who have RA and active disease.
3. For patients in group 3, treatment should be started with disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). 
4. For patients in group 2, treatment should be started with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or with glucocorticoids if patients are intolerant of NSAIDs. 
5. For patients in group 1, treatment should be started with NSAIDs. 
6. Strong recommendation: Patients should be evaluated for traditional risk factors for cardiovascular disease and should be treated according to current guidelines. 
7. Weak recommendation: Patients should have regular ophthalmologic evaluation and treatment according to current guidelines. 
8. The 2015 ACR recommendations for monitoring patients with RA can be used to monitor patients in daily practice. 
9. Strong recommendation: Patients with RA should receive pneumococcal vaccination and influenza vaccination. 
10. Weak recommendation: Patients with RA should receive influenza vaccination.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3: Currently, there are no guidelines for treating rheumatoid arthritis in middle-aged men.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v4:
"Middle-aged males" is not a disease. 

Rheumatoid arthritis is a disease.

There are no "newest approaches" to treating disease in general. There are newest approaches to treating specific patients with rheumatoid arthritis. 

Every patient is unique, and the treatment depends on:

patient's age, general health, and other medical conditions
type and severity of rheumatoid arthritis
patient's response to previous treatments

So, if you (the patient) have rheumatoid arthritis, you should ask:

What is my type of rheumatoid arthritis?
What are my other medical conditions?
What is my general health status?
What treatments have been effective for patients with my type of rheumatoid arthritis, my other medical conditions, and my general health status?

Then, your doctor will be able to provide you with the newest treatment for YOU.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v5:
The most recent advances in the management of rheumatoid arthritis for middle-aged men include the use of biologic agents such as etanercept and methotrexate. 

Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the joints, causing pain, swelling, and stiffness. Middle-aged men, in particular, are at a higher risk for developing rheumatoid arthritis.

The use of biologic agents such as etanercept and methotrexate have revolutionized the management of rheumatoid arthritis. These medications work by targeting specific aspects of the immune system to reduce inflammation and slow down joint damage.

It is important for individuals with rheumatoid arthritis to work closely with their healthcare providers to develop an individualized treatment plan that takes into account their specific symptoms and needs. Other treatment options for rheumatoid arthritis may include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, corticosteroids, and physical therapy.

I am afraid that as of right now, idebenone is not available as a treatment for Friedreich's ataxia, and it is unlikely that the individuals in question would be able to obtain it. medalpaca-13b_answer_v5:
2019 Update: There is still no cure for Friedreich's Ataxia.  Clinical trials are on-going, but no treatment has been approved.

Original Answer:
There is no cure for Friedreich's ataxia.  There are clinical trials underway, but there is no approved treatment.
Friedreich's ataxia is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.  This means a segment of DNA is repeated too many times.  This extra DNA causes a nonfunctional protein to be made.  The protein is nonfunctional because it has a changed shape.
There are many trinucleotide repeat disorders.  Some disorders have treatments.  For example, Huntington's disease has a treatment.  The treatment reduces the number of repeats so the nonfunctional protein is not made.
Researchers are working on treatments for other trinucleotide repeat disorders.  It is hard to develop treatments for these disorders because the repeats make the protein nonfunctional.  Researchers are working on ways to make the protein functional.
There are clinical trials underway for Friedreich's ataxia.  The clinical trials are testing to see if the nonfunctional protein can be made functional.  The clinical trials are in the early stages.  It will be a number of years before a treatment is found.
In the meantime, treatment for Friedreich's ataxia focuses on the symptoms.  For example, physical therapy can help with muscle weakness.  Anti-inflammatory medications can help with the inflammation that occurs in the heart.  Antioxidants can help protect the heart.  A dietician can help with a diet that will provide the best nutrition.

medalpaca-13b_answer_original:
1. What is vaginal prolapse?
Vaginal prolapse occurs when the tissue or organs in the vagina fall or sink lower than normal because of weakened or stretched muscles and ligaments.

2. Why does vaginal prolapse occur?
Vaginal prolapse can occur due to the following reasons:
Weakened or stretched muscles and ligaments that support the vagina and other pelvic organs. This can happen during childbirth, with menopause, after surgery or because of obesity. Changes in the pelvis due to menopause (when a woman stops having menstrual periods). The weight of the uterus before and after pregnancy. Chronic cough. Cystic fibrosis. Hysterectomy (surgery to remove the uterus). Obesity. Old age.

3. What are the different types of vaginal prolapse?
There are different types of vaginal prolapse: Cystocele: This type of vaginal prolapse occurs when the bladder drops into the vagina. Enterocele: This type of vaginal prolapse occurs when the small intestine (small bowel) drops into the vagina. Urethral diverticulum: This is a pouch or sac that forms in the tissue lining the vagina or urethra (the tube that carries urine out of the body). Vaginal septum: Thin tissue lining the vagina bulges into the vagina.

4. What are the symptoms of vaginal prolapse?
Vaginal prolapse can cause the vagina to slip or fall from its normal position, which can lead to the following symptoms: A feeling as if sitting on a small ball Difficult or painful sexual intercourse Protruding of the vagina through the opening Protruding of tissue outside the vagina through the opening of the vagina Slipping of the uterus into the vagina Vaginal noises (from air passing into the vagina) when walking or moving

5. How is vaginal prolapse diagnosed?
Vaginal prolapse is diagnosed during a pelvic examination.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1:
Vaginal repair surgery is a surgical procedure done to repair damage to the vagina, which can be caused by childbirth, menopause, or aging. Some of the common procedures include pelvic organ prolapse repair, vaginal wall repair, and enterocele repair. The specific procedure will depend on the type and severity of the prolapse.

The decision to undergo vaginal repair surgery is a personal one, and it's important to discuss the risks and benefits with your healthcare provider. In general, vaginal repair surgery can be effective in alleviating symptoms such as urinary incontinence, sexual dysfunction, and discomfort during intercourse. However, it's important to note that prolapse can recur even after surgery, and additional surgery may be required in the future. It's also possible that surgery may not alleviate all symptoms, and additional treatment may be necessary.

It's important to discuss your symptoms and concerns with your healthcare provider, who can help you determine if vaginal repair surgery is the right choice for you.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v2: The success rate for vaginal repair surgery is very high, and the chances of prolapse recurring even after the procedure are very low.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3: The real benefits of vaginal repair include cure of urinary incontinence, cure of sexual dysfunction, cure of obstruction, and prevention of further prolapse. The drawbacks of vaginal repair include the risks of surgery, such as anesthesia complications, infection complications, bleeding complications, injury complications, and failure of the surgery complications. The likelihood of another prolapse after vaginal repair is relatively low.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v4: It is important to understand that vaginal repair is not a permanent solution to your pelvic organ prolapse. While the surgery can help to alleviate many of your symptoms, it is not uncommon for women to require additional surgeries in the future. As with any surgery, vaginal repair has risks associated with it, such as infection, bleeding, and injury to other organs. It is important to discuss these risks with your healthcare provider before moving forward with surgery. Additionally, your healthcare provider can help to determine if vaginal repair is the best option for you, or if non-surgical interventions, such as pelvic floor physical therapy, would be a better choice.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v5:
There are no guarantees in medicine and gynecology is no exception.
However, vaginal repair surgery is successful in most of the cases.
The risk of surgery is the same as any other surgery such as excessive bleeding, infection, injury to nearby organs, etc.
In case of failure of surgery, the prolapse cannot be prevented. But the symptoms of prolapse will be there. So, it is important to follow-up the patient and evaluate the outcome of surgery.

medalpaca-13b_answer_v2:
Yes, there are many genetic syndromes which predispose to skin cancer.  The most important are:

1)    BRCA1/2 - associated with a significantly increased risk of melanoma 

2)    P53 - mutations in the tumor suppressor gene P53, which normally regulates cell growth and division, are present in a significant proportion of melanomas 

3)    BRAF - mutations in the BRAF gene have been found to be associated with increased risk of melanoma and non-melanoma skin cancer 

4)    PTEN - mutations in the PTEN tumor suppressor gene have been detected in a number of patients with familial and/or multiple melanomas 

5)    CDKN2A - also known as p16INK4a, is an important tumor suppressor gene in the pathogenesis of melanoma 

6)    PAX3 - PAX3 gene mutations have been observed to be associated with paul-neumann syndrome, which is characterized by the presence of a large number of cutaneous and oculodigital melanocytic nevi

medalpaca-13b_answer_v5: Yes, genetic predispositions can increase the risk of skin cancer in Caucasian adults. The risk of skin cancer is influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. In Caucasians, genetic factors account for 65% of the variation in skin cancer risk, with other factors such as UV exposure, smoking, and immune status making up the rest. Sun exposure is the most important environmental risk factor for skin cancer, but genetic factors like skin color, hair color, and the ability to tan can also affect a person's risk. For example, people with fair skin, light-colored hair, and a history of sunburns are at higher risk of developing skin cancer. In addition to genetic and environmental factors, aging, a history of skin damage, and a family history of skin cancer can also increase the risk of skin cancer. It is important for individuals to be aware of their personal risk factors for skin cancer and to take steps to reduce their risk through sun protection and regular skin cancer screenings.

medalpaca-13b_answer_original:
103.5 is a very high fever. Call your doctor immediately. Do not wait. This is an emergency. If you don't have a doctor, take her to the ER.

Fever in infants is very serious. The most common cause of fever this high is Shigella, a type of bacteria that causes severe dehydration. Other causes could be malaria, dengue, or hand-foot-mouth disease. All of these are emergencies.

Do not give your child any medication. Do not give her water. Do not bathe her. This is very important. Just call your doctor or take her to the ER immediately.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1:
1. Measure the temperature correctly. A rectal temperature of 103.5 degrees is equivalent to an oral temperature of 104.3 degrees. If you do not have a thermometer suited for rectal temperatures, an oral temperature is still helpful. Do not use an alcohol based thermometer. 
2. Give acetaminophen (Tylenol). This is the only medication you should give to reduce a fever. Give acetaminophen every 8 hours at 15 milliliters per dose. 
3. Keep your baby comfortable. Remove excess clothing and blankets. 
4. If the fever persists, you can give a second dose of acetaminophen 8 hours after the first dose. 
5. Call your doctor if the fever lasts more than 2 days, or if your baby becomes irritable, lethargic, or develops a rash.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v2: 103.5 is a high fever and it is recommended that you visit the ER. To help lower the temperature you can give acetaminophen or ibuprofen (DO NOT give both). You can also give a cool bath (make sure the water is not too cold). If the fever continues for more than 2 days, consult a doctor.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3: 103.5 is not a temperature that would cause significant concern in a 9 month old. I would recommend giving acetaminophen (Tylenol) at the recommended dose for the age of your child, making sure she is well hydrated, and monitoring the fever trend over time. I would not take her to the emergency room at this time. If the fever persists or rises above 104 degrees Fahrenheit I would reevaluate and may recommend a trip to the ER depending on other symptoms. Always call your doctor if you have concerns.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v4:
103.5 is not a particularly high fever in an 9 month old. You can safely monitor the fever and give acetaminophen (Tylenol) if you wish.

If the fever is accompanied by lethargy, poor feeding, or irritability; if the child has a rash; if the fever is 104F or higher, or if there are other concerning symptoms, then you should take the child to the ER. Otherwise, you can safely watch and wait.

Note: I am not a doctor, this is not medical advice, this is an answer to a question on a forum. If you have concerns about your child's health you should contact your doctor.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v5:
103.5 is high, but not emergency room high. For an infant though, it is high enough that you should be concerned. You should also be concerned if the fever is not accompanied by other symptoms, such as a runny nose or rash.

The best way to reduce a fever is with acetaminophen (Tylenol). You can give up to 15 mg/kg per dose, every 8 hours, but no more than 5 doses in a 24 hour period. If you are giving a nasal decongestant, you should wait 2 hours after the dose before giving acetaminophen.

If the fever is accompanied by other symptoms, such as irritability, not eating, or the child is acting sick, then you should consider taking them to the ER. If the fever is 104 or higher, go to the ER.

Other things you can do to help reduce a fever: give the child plenty of fluids to drink, give acetaminophen at least an hour before giving a cold medication, and use a cool sponge to reduce the temperature a few degrees. Do not use aspirin, as it has been associated with Reye's syndrome in children.

2. Insulin-dependent diabetes in children and adolescents is a result of autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β-cells.
3. The pathophysiology of type 1 diabetes mellitus involves genetic predisposition, environmental triggers, and autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β-cells by autoimmune cells.

medalpaca-13b_answer_v5:
There are no established causes for Juvenile diabetes (or what you call as insulin dependent diabetes). There are various types of diabetes and each has different causes.

Type 1 diabetes (juvenile onset)

This type of diabetes mellitus (T1DM) results from the body's failure to produce enough insulin. Only 5% of people with diabetes have T1DM.

With T1DM, the pancreas needs help to produce enough insulin to keep blood sugar levels normal. Insulin - producing cells in the pancreas are destroyed by the body's own immune system.

As the body makes less insulin, glucose builds up in the bloodstream instead of being used by the body for energy.

People with T1DM must take insulin regularly to replace the insulin the body cannot make on its own. Without insulin, the body's blood glucose concentration would continue to rise, leading to serious medical problems.

People with T1DM must carefully balance diet, physical activity, and insulin dose to avoid high and low blood glucose problems.

Type 2 diabetes

This type of diabetes mellitus (T2DM) results from the body's ineffective use of insulin. People with T2DM don't respond properly to insulin, though they may produce enough insulin.

As with T1DM, glucose builds up in the bloodstream instead of being used by the body for energy.

People with T2DM may require insulin or other medications to control their blood glucose levels. They may also need to make significant changes in diet and exercise patterns.

Gestational diabetes

Gestational diabetes is a temporary condition that occurs during pregnancy.

Gestational diabetes occurs in 2% to 5% of all pregnancies and may resolve after delivery.

Gestational diabetes occurs when the body cannot produce enough insulin to handle the increased glucose levels during pregnancy.

Gestational diabetes is generally does not cause lasting effects on the mother, although it may increase the risk for the mother

medalpaca-13b_answer_original: There is mixed evidence for the benefit of physical therapy on tension headaches. A 2014 systematic review found "compelling evidence" to support the use of physical therapy for tension headaches,  while a 2017 systematic review found "weak evidence" to support the use of physical therapy for tension headaches.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1:
1.  It can be learned by the patient as a self-help technique.

medalpaca-13b_answer_v2:
There is mixed evidence for the benefit of physical therapy in the treatment of tension headaches. In a systematic review and meta-analysis, researchers analyzed data from 26 studies that examined the effect of physical therapy on patients with tension-type headache.  The researchers found that physical therapy was more effective in reducing headache days per month and improving quality of life compared with no treatment or usual care. However, the benefit of physical therapy was small and was possibly due to an increase in neck mobility. The researchers concluded that physical therapy may be a useful, additional tool in the treatment of tension-type headache. 

However, in another study, researchers found that there was no difference between those who received light to moderate massage and those who did not, in terms of headache frequency, pain intensity, or satisfaction. 

In conclusion, the evidence is mixed for the benefit of physical therapy in the treatment of tension headaches.

4 A.M. Blood pressure (BP) spikes are a common phenomenon and there are multiple reasons for it. Let us discuss the most likely causes:

1.  The BP medicines that you are taking, need to be taken at least 30-45 minutes before meals. If they are taken immediately after meals, they get diluted and lose their effect.
2.  The BP medicines that act on the kidneys to reduce salt and water retention, if taken at night, may lead to reduced BP and hence the spike when you wake up.
3.  If you are on calcium channel blockers, they may cause a dip in BP shortly after you go to sleep and then the BP may rise when you wake up.
4.  If you are a smoker, stop smoking.
5.  Do not consume alcohol, if any.
6.  Lose weight if you are obese.
7.  Avoid excessive caffeine intake.
8.  Exercise regularly.
9.  Lastly, if the above measures do not help, you may require additional medicines to prevent the 4 A.M. BP spikes.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1:
Yes, this is a common occurrence. The body has a circadian rhythm which is a 24-hour cycle. This includes blood pressure. While the exact cause of this is unknown, it is thought that there is a hormonal and nervous system contribution.

It is important to know that just because you have high blood pressure at night does not necessarily mean that your blood pressure is uncontrolled. It is important to monitor and control blood pressure throughout the day, but especially at night.

There are several things you can do to help control blood pressure at night.

1)  Try to avoid alcohol, caffeine, and smoking at least 6 hours before bedtime.
2)  Exercise regularly, but avoid strenuous exercise too close to bedtime.
3)  Avoid stress right before bedtime.
4)  Make sure you are not ill, and get medical treatment if you are.
5)  Talk to your doctor about your medications, as sometimes changing medications can help.
6)  Try to go to sleep and wake up at the same time every day.
7)  Avoid eating right before bedtime.
8)  Make sure your room is dark, quiet, and not too cold or too hot at night.
9)  If you have a chronic condition such as kidney disease or heart failure, talk to your doctor about medication adjustments.
10)  Continue to monitor your blood pressure throughout the day and night.

It is important to talk to your doctor about any concerns you have about your blood pressure. They can help guide you in the right direction and adjust medications as needed.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v2:
It is a known phenomenon and there are various reasons for it. One of the reasons is the so-called "hyperdynamic" circulatory system, where the heart beats very rapidly (over 100 per minute) and strong pulses are sent through the blood vessels resulting in the spiking of the blood pressure. Another reason is the "hyperresponsive" circulatory system, where even a small amount of fluid shifts into the blood vessels, causing the blood pressure to shoot up. 

There are other reasons which are more common and more specific, such as sleep apnea (temporary cessation of breathing during sleep, leading to excessive secretion of the stress hormone and increased blood pressure upon awakening), kidney disease, diabetes, etc.

I advise you to consult your doctor and set up a plan to monitor your blood pressure at different times of the day and night.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3:
24 hour blood pressure monitoring will give you an exact picture. It is usual that BP is little elevated at night, but if the spikes are significant, then you have a problem.
It is also possible that you are misreading your BP, or it could be a faulty BP monitor. Check if you can get a blood pressure reading when you are calm, seated for 5 minutes. If you can do that, then it could be a faulty BP monitor.
Also, check your BP at the same time every day, and take readings for a week, and then show it to your doctor.

medalpaca-13b_answer_original: Glaucoma is an eye disease caused by increased pressure in the eye. This pressure can lead to damage of the optic nerve and result in vision loss or blindness. The cause of the high pressure is an abnormal drainage system in the eye. In some cases, glaucoma is associated with eye injury, eye infection, or family history of the disease. Glaucoma can affect one or both eyes. People of all ages can develop glaucoma. The disease is most commonly diagnosed among adults, but it may also be found in children. African Americans over age 40 are at higher risk for the disease than other races. Other risk factors include a family history of glaucoma, high eye pressure, severe myopia, history of eye injury or surgery, and certain medical conditions such as diabetes and hypertension. Treatment of glaucoma aims to reduce the pressure in the eye. This can be accomplished through medications, laser surgery, or surgical procedures that create a new drainage channel for the eye. Early diagnosis and treatment of glaucoma is important to prevent or slow the loss of vision. A person with glaucoma should be reevaluated at regular intervals to determine whether the treatment is working and to prevent complications.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1:
Glaucoma is an eye disease in which the internal eye pressure increases, causing damage to the optic nerve and possible loss of vision. The condition is often painless and progresses slowly.

Most often, the cause of glaucoma is unknown. A common form of glaucoma is called open-angle glaucoma. It is painless and gradual, and is most often associated with increased age.

Another form of glaucoma is closed-angle glaucoma, which is much less common than open-angle glaucoma. Closed-angle glaucoma develops rapidly and is much more serious than open-angle glaucoma.

Regular eye examinations are strongly recommended in order to diagnose glaucoma as early as possible and to prevent serious vision loss. Treatment of glaucoma may include medications, laser therapy, or surgery.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v2:
1. What is glaucoma?
Glaucoma is a group of eye diseases in which the optic nerve is damaged, causing loss of peripheral vision.  The optic nerve is a cable like structure which is responsible for transmitting the visual image from the eye to the brain. Damage to the optic nerve causes holes or defects in the visual field, which is the map of the visual world around us. Holes in the visual field can vary in size and shape. As the holes in the visual field increase in size and number, peripheral (side) vision is lost and objects in the visual field are detected later in the visual process. Holes in the visual field may also occur in a specific location in the visual field.
2. What are the different types of glaucoma?
Open angle glaucoma
Open-angle glaucoma is the most common form of glaucoma. It is a chronic condition that develops so gradually that it often goes unnoticed until vision is impaired. Open-angle glaucoma is painless and causes no visible problems in the early stages. It is often associated with elevated eye pressure.
Angle-closure glaucoma
Angle-closure glaucoma is a form of glaucoma which occurs when the fluid in the eye is unable to drain properly through the angle between the iris and the cornea. This causes a sudden rise of pressure in the eye which may cause severe pain and redness. It is often associated with a decreased vision in the affected eye(s).
Low-tension or normal-tension glaucoma
Low-tension or normal-tension glaucoma is a form of glaucoma which occurs in patients with a normal or low eye pressure. Beta blocker medications, used to treat conditions such as hypertension, may cause low eye pressure.
Congenital glaucoma
Congenital glaucoma is a form of glaucoma which occurs in children. It may be caused by an abnormality in the drainage system of the eye, or by an obstruction of the drainage system, which leads to an excessive buildup of fluid in the eye, thereby causing damage to the optic nerve.
Secondary glaucomas
Second
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3: Glaucoma is an eye disease caused by increased pressure in the eye. The increased pressure occurs when the fluid inside the eye is unable to drain through the natural ducts. It can be inherited or caused by certain diseases, eye injuries, or medications. Treatment for glaucoma is to lower the pressure in the eye. This is done with medications, laser surgery, or surgical procedures. Regular eye exams are important to detect glaucoma before permanent vision loss occurs.

It's caused by an imbalance between the production and drainage of the fluid in the eye. People with open angle glaucoma often have no symptoms until they begin to lose vision Gradual loss of peripheral (side) vision (also called tunnel vision) is the most common symptom of glaucoma.

Open angle glaucoma is painless Thus, it is important to have regular eye exams to detect the disease and prevent vision loss.

Regular eye exams are the best way to protect your vision. The optic nerve can be damaged by glaucoma even when the intraocular pressure is only slightly high.

Because the disease progresses slowly, a person can lose a significant amount of vision before being aware of it.

The second, less common, form of glaucoma is acute angle closure glaucoma. It occurs suddenly when the fluid in the eye is unable to drain. This results in a rapid increase of pressure in the eye. Symptoms include:

Severe eye pain Vision loss in one eye Nausea and vomiting

If you have symptoms of acute angle closure glaucoma seek medical care immediately.

Early detection and treatment of open angle glaucoma can prevent vision loss. Treatment may include:

Medications to lower intraocular pressure Surgery to create a new drainage channel for the fluid in the eye (called a trabeculectomy) Laser surgery to improve fluid drainage

If you have glaucoma, your doctor may recommend that you check your intraocular pressure at home. This is especially important if you have open angle glaucoma.

Measuring intraocular pressure at home is not necessary if you have acute angle closure glaucoma, because the pressure can suddenly spike and cause symptoms.

Measuring intraocular pressure at home involves using a tonometer. Your doctor or eye care provider will show you how to use the tonometer and how to keep it clean.

medalpaca-13b_answer_original: There is a very small study that was published in the Journal of Child Neurology that showed an increased incidence of autism in patients with Leber congenital amaurosis (LCA).  The study was small with only 9 patients with LCA being evaluated.  Five of the 9 patients were found to have some level of autism.  The study's authors suggested that there may be a relationship between LCA and autism, but more study is needed to determine if there is a cause and effect relationship.  The study can be found at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16345854
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1: There is a very recent publication in the New England Journal of Medicine that describes an association between congenital blindness (Leber's congenital amaurosis - LCA) and autism.  The article is titled "Recurrent de novo Mutations in a Gene That Encodes a Connexon-Associated Protein" by K.M. O'Brien et al. It can be found in the June 26, 2003 issue (Volume 348, Number 26, Pages 2228-2233, DOI: 10.1056/NEJM200306263482609).  The gene that is mutated is GJB2, which encodes the gap junction protein connexon 26.  The authors found 11 individuals with LCA and autism who had a mutation in this gene that was not found in either parent.  This is very strong evidence for a direct association between this gene and both LCA and autism.  The gene is on chromosome 3, while LCA is usually due to a recessive trait, this may be an interesting avenue for further study.

1. Topical treatment: This is the first-line treatment for scalp psoriasis. Topical treatment involves the use of creams, lotions or shampoos that are applied directly to the affected area of the scalp. Some commonly used topical treatments include:

a. Vitamin D analogs: This includes calcipotriene, which is commonly prescribed for the treatment of scalp psoriasis.

b. Topical steroids: These are used to reduce inflammation and itching associated with scalp psoriasis.

c. Salicylic acid: This is a commonly used ingredient in shampoos for scalp psoriasis, as it helps remove scales from the scalp.

2. Phototherapy: This involves the use of ultraviolet light to help reduce the scaling and inflammation associated with scalp psoriasis.

3. Systemic treatment: This is used for more severe cases of scalp psoriasis, where the above treatments have been ineffective. Systemic treatment involves the use of medications that are taken orally or by injection, and which work by suppressing the immune system. Some commonly used systemic medications for the treatment of scalp psoriasis include:

a. Methotrexate: This is commonly used as a systemic treatment for scalp psoriasis, as it helps suppress the immune system and reduce inflammation.

b. Biologic agents: This is a newer class of medications that work by targeting specific components of the immune system that contribute to the development of scalp psoriasis. Some commonly used biologic agents for the treatment of scalp psoriasis include:

i. Ustekinumab
ii. Secukinumab
iii. Ixekizumab

It is important to note that the choice of treatment for scalp psoriasis may vary depending on the individual's age, overall health, and the severity of the condition. It is recommended to consult a dermatologist for the appropriate diagnosis and treatment of scalp psoriasis.

CT scan findings suggestive of diverticulitis include abscesses, gas bubbles, thickening of the colon wall, and outpouchings. In some cases, biopsy may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1: CT can detect diverticulosis but not diverticulitis when there is no active infection. Diverticulosis is a condition in which small pouches (diverticula) develop in the wall of the colon. It is usually asymptomatic and does not require treatment unless it becomes symptomatic. Diverticulitis, on the other hand, is a condition in which the diverticula become inflamed or infected. It can cause symptoms such as abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits. While CT can be used to diagnose both conditions, only diverticulitis shows up on CT when there is active infection. Diverticulosis is usually only detected on colonoscopy.

Dentures
Radiation therapy to head and neck
Certain autoimmune conditions
Certain endocrine conditions
Nerve damage in the head and neck

medalpaca-13b_answer_v3:
Question:  My doctor is not familiar with an oral medication for dry mouth, but I've done some research and think it might exist - can you help me identify the name of this medication so I can ask my doctor to prescribe it?

Context: You are a helpful doctor answering patient questions. 
Answer: Two medications commonly used to treat xerostomia or dry mouth are pilocarpine and cevimline. Pilocarpine is a natural component of saliva and is used to stimulate saliva and moisten mouth tissues. It is available in gel, liquid, and tablet form and is taken several times a day. Cevimline is a synthetic version of a substance found in saliva that prevents the breakdown of mucus. It is also taken several times a day and is available in tablet form. Both of these medications are available by prescription only and should be taken under the guidance of a medical professional. It is important to discuss the risks and benefits of these medications with your doctor before starting treatment.

37 years old is a bit young for gastric reflux disease (GRD), but not too young.  It is good that you have already ruled out anxiety as a cause of your chest pain.
Heartburn is a burning pain caused by stomach acid irritating the esophagus.  It is commonly caused by a hiatal hernia, which is a condition where the top of the stomach sticks up into the chest.
It is important to know if you also have difficulty swallowing, or a feeling of something stuck in your throat, as this could be a sign of something more serious, such as esophageal cancer.
If your symptoms are mild, then dietary changes and lifestyle changes can help.  Mild symptoms means that you only have heartburn a few times a week.
1) Dietary Changes
-Eat smaller meals more frequently.
-Avoid trigger foods, such as spicy foods, citrus fruits and juices, tomato sauces, chocolate, mints, alcohol, and coffee.
-Eat foods that neutralize stomach acid, such as bananas, rice, and bread.
-Avoid lying down within 3 hours of a meal.
2) Lifestyle Changes
-Lose weight if overweight.
-Quit smoking and alcohol if you have these vices.
-Wear clothing that is loose around the waist.
-Avoid stressful situations.
-Practice relaxation techniques such as yoga or meditation.
If your symptoms are more severe, you may need medication in addition to dietary and lifestyle changes.  Severe symptoms means that you have heartburn every day, or heartburn that lasts for more than a few hours a day.
1) Medications
-Antacids: Can be purchased over-the-counter.  Work by neutralizing stomach acid.
-H2-receptor blockers: Can be purchased over-the-counter.  Work by reducing the amount of acid the stomach produces.
-Proton pump inhibitors: Prescription.  Work by turning off the acid producing pumps in the stomach.
-Foaming agents: Prescription.

medalpaca-13b_answer_original: There are no risk factors for HELP syndrome in the mother, apart from a previous history of HELP syndrome. HELP syndrome occurs in about 1 to 2% of all pregnancies. Therefore, your sister having HELLP in a previous pregnancy increases your risk of having HELLP in a subsequent pregnancy. However, it is not a 100% risk. There are other factors that can increase your risk of having HELLP, such as obesity, certain medical conditions (such as thrombophilia), certain ethnic groups (such as Italian, Chinese, Indigenous Australian and Mexican), multiple pregnancies (such as twins or triplets) and age (such as younger than 18 or older than 35). Therefore, it is important for you to be aware of the symptoms of HELLP, such as blurred vision, severe headaches, extreme nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and changes in your urine (such as dark, red or no urine). If you experience any of these symptoms, you should contact your doctor immediately. Your doctor will assess your condition and order the necessary tests and treatment. I hope this answers your question.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v1:
The data on risk of HELLP syndrome in a subsequent pregnancy is a bit conflicting. A large study found that the risk of HELLP syndrome in a subsequent pregnancy was 1.6% (about 1 in 60), but this risk increased to 9.4% (about 1 in 10) if the initial pregnancy also had HELLP syndrome.  Other studies have found a lower risk of recurrence, about 0.5-1%. 
Regardless, it is clear that the risk of HELLP syndrome in a subsequent pregnancy is higher if the first pregnancy had HELLP syndrome. You may want to discuss this with your doctor and consider screening for HELLP syndrome in your second pregnancy.
Even if the risk is low, it is still important to watch for symptoms of HELLP syndrome, which include severe headache, visual changes, severe nausea and vomiting, and abdominal pain.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v2:
HELLP syndrome is a severe version of preeclampsia that can occur in pregnancy. It is a condition that can affect both the mother and baby. HELLP stands for hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets.

The exact cause of HELLP syndrome is not clear. Doctors believe it is related to problems with the blood vessels of the liver.
HELLP syndrome can be more common in women who have had the condition in a previous pregnancy. Having a family history of HELLP syndrome may also be a risk factor. 
Other risk factors for HELLP syndrome include:
First pregnancy Multiple pregnancy (twins or more) Obesity Older than age 35 Past history of preeclampsia
medalpaca-13b_answer_v3: The overall probability is 1-5%, but this depends on whether you have a history of preeclampsia, eclampsia, or HELLP syndrome in your family. If your sister is the only one in your family with these conditions, the probability for you would be 1-2%. If your mother or another sister also has a history, the probability for you would be 5%. This is just an estimate, and your personal probability can vary depending on your family history and other factors. I recommend talking to your doctor about this and any other concerns you may have.
medalpaca-13b_answer_v4: Your risk of developing HELLP syndrome is 10 times higher than the general population. HELLP syndrome is a severe version of preeclampsia that includes liver and platelet abnormalities in addition to high blood pressure. It typically occurs in the second half of pregnancy. Symptoms include severe headaches, blurry vision, swelling, and pain in the upper right part of the abdomen. It is important to seek medical attention if you are at risk for HELLP syndrome and develop any of these symptoms.
